author: feed_watermark
title: Australia munitions aid â€˜wonâ€™t be the lastâ€™ for Ukraine
text:
Ukraine has welcomed Australiaâ€™s largest military aid package that includes air defence missiles, air-to-ground weapons and anti-tank weapons with its envoy signalling a defence pact as a logical next step.
Defence Minister Richard Marles unveiled a $250 million package during a NATO security summit in Washington, focused on Ukraineâ€™s security amid Russiaâ€™s ongoing war.
There was renewed emphasis on air defence systems after a barrage of Russian missiles killed about 40 people across the country and struck a childrenâ€™s hospital in the capital Kyiv.
ğŸ¤ Many thanks to Australia for announcing the largest single military assistance package, worth nearly $250 million.
At the NATO Summit @RichardMarlesMP reaffirmed Australiaâ€™s commitment to standing with Ukraine in its defence against Russiaâ€™s illegal and immoral invasion. 1/3 pic.twitter.com/f0RfM9gg1L
â€” Embassy of Ukraine in Australia and New Zealand (@UKRinAUS) July 11, 2024
Ukrainian ambassador to Australia Vasyl Myroshnychenko welcomed the new package, saying the air defences were exactly what his nation needed.
â€œIâ€™m very pleased to see the Australian government is stepping up assistance to Ukraine,â€ he told AAP.
â€œI think this is also a reaction to what Russia is doing here in the region, what Russia is doing with North Korea after the signing of the security agreement.â€
Russia and China signing a â€œno limitsâ€ pact on the eve of Moscowâ€™s invasion â€œwas hugely consequential for the worldâ€ and those in the Indo-Pacific would take lessons from what happened in Ukraine, Mr Marles said.
Australia supported NATO nations branding China a â€œdecisive enablerâ€, he said.
 Air defences are exactly what Ukraine needs, ambassador to Australia Vasyl Myroshnychenko says. Image by Mick Tsikas/AAP PHOTOS A bilateral security or defence pact between the two nations, similar to what other G7 countries had signed with Ukraine, â€œwould be a logical step forward given how consistent Australian support isâ€, Mr Myroshnychenko said.
Australia would continue to work with Ukraine around what support was needed to counter Russiaâ€™s invasion, Mr Marles said when asked about such an agreement.
Australiaâ€™s intent and reliability had been completely clear and this wouldnâ€™t be the last aid package for Ukraine, he said.
â€œThe conversations that weâ€™ve been having with Ukraine, really the focus has been on providing the support, the particular support that Ukraine has been seeking, and obviously at a scale which is meaningful to them,â€ he told ABC Radio.
â€œThey know we are there for the long term â€¦ and weâ€™ll continue to engage with them on that basis.â€
Mr Marles met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy alongside other leaders from the so-called Indo-Pacific four nations on the sideline of the summit.
In addition to the new missiles Australia will supply artillery, mortar, cannon and small arms ammunition as well as a shipment of boots.
Australia will also join NATOâ€™s new security and training initiative for Ukraine as a non-member partner, enabling defence personnel to contribute to planning and NATO-led military activity.
A small number of people who are already working in Europe will transfer to the NATO initiative in the first instance, Mr Marles said.
 Defence Minister Richard Marles says the latest Ukraine assistance package will not be the last. Image by Lukas Coch/AAP PHOTOS The defence minister also signed a memorandum of understanding on the drone coalition for Ukraine while in Washington.
The US also announced further air defence aid for Ukraine, with former Ukrainian defence minister Andriy Zagorodnyuk saying the recent barrage of Russian rockets showed they â€œlearned how to overwhelm existing systemsâ€.
NATO nations also needed to work on a plan to end the war rather than prop up Ukraineâ€™s defence, so it does not continue to drag on, he said.
Opposition foreign spokesman Simon Birmingham welcomed the latest round of military aid, saying Ukraineâ€™s fight was â€œa test of the willingness of leading democracies to stand firm against aggressionâ€.
â€œAdditional Australian support for Ukraine is welcome, especially the provision of missiles and weapons so clearly needed to defeat Russia,â€ he said on social media platform X.
